resource_data.description: Here are some useful links and documents:

resource.title: ICMJE: Recommendations for the Conduct, Reporting, Editing and Publication of Scholarly Work in Medical Journals

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript:
Welcome to Authorship Guidelines. The company has developed these guidelines to provide clear information to authors and potential authors about assumptions, expectations, and requirements, and about the criteria used to determine authorship for publication of information from Sponsored Clinical Trials and Post Marketing Commitment Studies.

Before beginning, we’ll first take a minute to review the main the functionalities available to you for navigating this course.

Most people who choose to participate in writing a manuscript or making a presentation do so to achieve a purpose. The company has developed these guidelines to provide clear information for potential authors, co-authors and other contributors that can help them understand how to meet necessary requirements and achieve our mutual purpose.

Guidelines offer clear, explicit information to help authors and potential authors understand the key assumptions behind policies for the dissemination of findings; the criteria used to determine authorship and order of authorship as well as to receive acknowledgement for contributions to manuscripts and presentations. We’ll also touch on some of the responsibilities of authors, and provide information on requirements for publication pre-approval, on the approval process and on resources for additional information.

One of the most important things for authors and potential authors to understand about authorship guidelines is the four criteria used to determine who is eligible to be listed as an author.

In order to be included as an author, a person must, first, have made a substantial contribution to either the manuscript’s conception and design, to the acquisition of data, or to analysis and interpretation of the data presented.

Keep in mind that contributions to the leadership, design, analysis, data quality, and study conduct (including enrollment) are all considered for determining authorship.

Second, each author must have been involved in drafting the manuscript or in making critical revisions of important intellectual content in it.

Third, those with authorship credit must provide final approval of the content for publication.

And finally, everyone listed as an author must agree to be accountable for all aspects of the work, and must ensure that questions related to the accuracy or integrity of any part of the work are appropriately investigated and resolved.

These and other criteria presented here are based on recommendations developed by the International Committee of Medical Journal Editors. For a link to a pdf of their recommendations, click the resources tab in the upper right corner of this player.

Many peer-reviewed journals and major genetics meetings limit the number of authors who can be credited, so the number of possible authors for any publication or presentation are based on the specific conference or meeting, or the specific journal. While there are cases in which no limit is set on the number of authors, limits on the number of authors are common.

For example, while the Journal of Inherited Metabolic Disease does not limit the number of authors, Skeletal Radiology allows a maximum of 7 authors for their publications. Generally, publications and meetings with limits to the number of authors allow no exceptions.

For that reason, our company recommends a maximum of 4 internal staff for inclusion as authors on a publication. This is to ensure that our investigators’ contributions are highlighted in publications and presentations.

The order of authorship of involved investigators will be based on the relative contribution of each one.

Investigator authorship will be based on the number of eligible subjects enrolled and the data provided. First and Senior authors will be those investigators who are the lead enrollers of subjects for whom data are per-protocol and can be evaluated for efficacy and safety.

Co-Authorship credit will be given to investigators who had significant enrollment and contributions of quality data.

Individuals who do not meet the definition of an author, but who had a substantive role in revising the manuscript or consulting on the final publication, must be acknowledged in any resulting publication.

Whenever feasible, we expect to include the majority of investigators who participated in a study. If there is a limit on the number of authors imposed by the journal, all investigators who participated will be acknowledged or included in an addendum of study investigators.

Let’s take a minute to review some of the information we’ve covered so far. For this drag and drop knowledge check, drag each open book in the top right of the screen to the appropriate group of books on the shelf below and drop it there. If the open book describes one of the requirements for authorship, drop it in the Author section of the shelf. If it describes requirements for receiving Acknowledgment in a publication, drop it in the Acknowledgements section of the shelf.

An internal review and approval by our company is required for all manuscripts and abstracts prior to submission. This is a necessity whether the idea for publication has been initiated by our company---or by someone from outside the company, if one of the co-authors is from our company, as well as when we have provided support and/or data for the publication.

This requirement is in keeping with our responsibility, and our right, to evaluate a proposed submission on the basis of scientific accuracy and consistency with our database. The review process also ensures that information is presented in a non-promotional and fair and balanced way, and that proprietary information is both appropriately used and appropriate to release.

Those interested in publishing should be aware that our company’s internal review process can take from 10 business days to 30 business days or more, depending on the information that will be covered. For example: Abstracts and posters, on average, require at least 10 business days (2 weeks), manuscripts take at least 15 business days (3 weeks); and cases involving intellectual property issues can take at least 30 business days (6 weeks) for review. Additional time will be required in those instances where our company wishes to file a patent application regarding an invention that is disclosed in a manuscript.

Journals have their own specific guidelines and schedules for submissions, but it’s important that authors incorporate additional time into their submission planning to allow time for this review process.

It is also important for all authors and potential authors to understand two other requirements for authorship. We require that authorship contributions are made in a timely manner; and a written response that indicates either approval to be included as an author, or disapproval---when someone chooses not to be listed as an author, or requires changes be made to the document in order to enable his/her inclusion. A written indication that a contributor chooses to be excluded from the list of authors prevents unnecessary confusion and delays in the submission process.

But for the majority of substantive contributors who will choose to be listed as co-authors, keep in mind that lack of response is not interpreted as an approval, so failure to provide written approval within the needed timeframe can result in deletion from the list of authors.

Let’s take a minute to remember the minimum times needed for the review process, that you’ll want to consider for publication planning. Drag each of the estimated time requirements listed on the right to the associated publication activity listed on the left.

Successful score:

Congratulations! You’ve passed the Knowledge Checks and nearly completed this course. If you’d like to replay any information presented, click any item in the Menu to open that section and review the information in it. Or click the “Next” button for some closing information and resources.

Failure score:

It looks like you made a few mistakes on the Knowledge Checks. If you’d like to replay any information presented, use the Menu to navigate to any topic.

To review the specific information related to the Knowledge Checks, first select the “Introduction and General Information” section to open it. Then, to see requirements for approval

•Select “Pre-Publication Approval Requirements”

Or to see information on the average times needed for the review process

•Select “Pre-Publication Average Approval Times”

Click the “Next” button for closing information and resources.

This sample is the introductory segment of a more extensive training course, and is used here to demonstrate some typical practices I use in my work. Thank you for your time and attention today. I hope you enjoyed it.
